summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan in response to Ghislaine Maxwell's complaint about delays in receiving legal mail at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). The government explains the MDC's standard mail processing procedures and states that an institutional emergency caused a one-day delay in delivering a hard drive containing court-ordered disclosures to Maxwell.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Ghislaine Maxwell case who issued the order requiring the government to respond to Maxwell's complaint about legal mail delivery.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case, held at the Metropolitan Detention Center, whose legal mail delivery was the subject of the court filing.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter to the court.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in the criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding.
Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against Maxwell.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell complained about delays in receiving legal mail while held at the Metropolitan Detention Center.
The government explained that an institutional emergency at the MDC on October 13, 2021, prevented delivery of legal mail to all inmates that day.
A hard drive containing court-ordered disclosures was delivered to Maxwell on October 14, 2021, after being received by the MDC on October 12.
Judge Nathan declined to issue Maxwell's requested order but expressed the firm expectation that a pre-trial defendant should receive legal mail within approximately one business day.
The MDC's legal department serves approximately 1,700 inmates and follows standard procedures for processing legal mail.
